Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
Response:
Number the six coastal villages 0,1,2,3,4,5 in clockwise order.
Assume the brothers all live in village 0.  
The girls live in the first three villages met going clockwise, i.e. in
villages 1, 2 and 3.  
Because every pair of villages is joined by a straight path, the interior
network is the complete graph K₆ drawn on the six vertices of a regular
hexagon.

For any fixed destination v the rule
“always getting closer to v’’ orients each edge:
u → w is allowed exactly when the Euclidean distance |w v| is strictly
smaller than |u v|.
Hence a route is a directed path in this acyclic digraph.

1.  Groom whose fiancée is in village 1  
   Distances from village 1:  
   |01|=|21| (=1), |31|=|51|(=√3), |41| (=2).  
   Village 0 is already in the group closest to 1, so the only permitted
   step is the direct edge 0 → 1.  
   Number of routes = 1.  
   He brings one fish on 1 April, wedding on 2 April.

2.  Groom whose fiancée is in village 2  
   Distance classes from 2:  
   nearest 1,3; middle 0,4; farthest 5.  
   Starting in village 0 (middle class) the allowed first steps are  
   0 → 1, 0 → 3, 0 → 2.  
   From 1 or 3 one can only go on to the destination 2.
   Therefore the routes are  
     0 → 2, 0 → 1 → 2, 0 → 3 → 2.  
   Number of routes = 3.  
   He fishes on 1–3 April, wedding on 4 April.

3.  Groom whose fiancée is in village 3  
   Distance classes from 3:  
   nearest 2,4; middle 1,5; farthest 0.  
   From the start 0 the possible moves are to 1,2,3,4,5.  
   Counting paths in the oriented graph gives
      0 → 3,  
      0 → 1 → 3, 0 → 5 → 3,  
      0 → 1 → 2 → 3, 0 → 1 → 4 → 3,  
      0 → 5 → 2 → 3, 0 → 5 → 4 → 3,  
      0 → 2 → 3, 0 → 4 → 3.  
   Total routes = 9.  
   He fishes on 1–9 April, wedding on 10 April.

Hence
• first wedding: 2 April  
• second wedding: 4 April  
• third wedding: 10 April.

Bonus (island circumference 10 mi).  
Radius r = 10 / (2π) = 5/π miles.  
Chord lengths:
60° chord  = 2r sin 30° = r = 5/π ≈ 1.592 mi,  
180° chord = 2r = 10/π ≈ 3.183 mi.

The longest permitted route is  
0 → 1 (60°) → 4 (180°) → 3 (60°)  
or its mirror image; its length is  

2·(5/π) + 10/π = 20/π ≈ 6.37 miles.

Final answer: 2 April, 4 April, 10 April.  Bonus: the longest route is 20/π ≈ 6.37 miles.

Response:
Number the six coast‑villages 0,1,2,3,4,5 in the clockwise order round the island.  
The sons live with their father in village 0.  
The three brides live in the next three villages encountered clockwise, i.e. in villages 1, 2 and 3.

For each pair of villages there is one straight jungle path (a chord of the circum­ference), so the graph on the six villages is the complete graph K₆.  
When a suitor is travelling to his fiancée’s village he may pass through other villages, but after every step he must be strictly nearer to the goal than he was before.  
Thus, for a fixed destination the chords become directed from “farther” to “nearer”, and the admissible trips are exactly the directed paths in that directed acyclic graph.

-------------------------------------------------
Counting the admissible trips
-------------------------------------------------

Distances depend only on the central angle.  
If R is the radius of the island,

 angle 60°  →  chord = R  
 angle 120° →  chord = R√3  
 angle 180° →  chord = 2R  

1.  Destination 1 (village 1)

distance to 1 : village 4 = 2R > 1.732R  
       village 3,5 = R√3 (≈1.732R)  
       village 0,2 = R  
       village 1 = 0  

From village 0 (distance R) the only vertex that is strictly nearer is the goal itself, so there is exactly

 N₁ = 1 trip : 0 → 1

2.  Destination 2 (village 2)

distance to 2 : village 5 = 2R  
       village 0,4 = R√3  
       village 1,3 = R  
       village 2 = 0  

From 0 (distance R√3) one can move to 1 or 3 (distance R) or directly to 2.  
From 1 or 3 one can only move to 2.  
Hence

 Trips : 0→2 , 0→1→2 , 0→3→2  

 N₂ = 3 trips.

3.  Destination 3 (village 3)

distance to 3 : village 0 = 2R  
       village 1,5 = R√3  
       village 2,4 = R  
       village 3 = 0  

Write A=0, B=1, C=5, D=2, E=4, F=3 and list levels:

 level 3 : A (2R)  
 level 2 : B, C (R√3)  
 level 1 : D, E (R)  
 level 0 : F (0)

All chords exist, but only those that go to a lower level may be used.

Paths counted from the bottom upward

 g(F)=1  
 g(D)=g(E)=1  
 g(B)=1 (B→F)+1 (B→D→F)+1 (B→E→F)=3  
 g(C)=3 (by symmetry)  
 g(A)=1 (A→F)+g(B)+g(C)+g(D)+g(E)  
   =1+3+3+1+1 = 9

 N₃ = 9 trips.

-------------------------------------------------
The wedding days
-------------------------------------------------

Each suitor begins on 1 April and makes one different trip each day.
The couple marry the day after he has completed his last required trip.

 Son to village 1 : 1 day  → wedding 2 April  
 Son to village 2 : 3 days → wedding 4 April  
 Son to village 3 : 9 days → wedding 10 April

-------------------------------------------------
Bonus – the longest single trip
-------------------------------------------------

The coastline is 10 mi, so

 2πR = 10  ⇒  R = 5/π miles ≈ 1.5916 mi.

Among the 9 admissible trips to village 3 the longest is

 0 → 1 (R) → 4 (2R) → 3 (R) or 0 → 5 (R) → 2 (2R) → 3 (R)

Total length = R + 2R + R = 4R = 20/π miles ≈ 6.37 mi.

-------------------------------------------------
Final answer: 
The weddings take place on 2 April, 4 April, and 10 April.  
The longest route any of the sons must walk is 20/π ≈ 6.37 miles.

Response:
I am sorry – after many attempts I still cannot obtain a fully‑coherent, unambiguous interpretation of the story that lets me turn it into a single well–posed mathematical counting problem.  In particular

• It is not clear exactly which three villages are the brides’ villages and which three are the suitors’ villages.  
• It is not clear whether the coastline arcs count as permissible “routes” (the text seems to exclude them, but later sentences could be read the other way).  
• Most importantly, the rule that the suitor must “always be getting closer” to the destination can be interpreted in several nonequivalent ways (strictly decreasing straight–line distance at every intermediate point, strictly decreasing only at the nodes visited, non‑increase, etc.).  Each interpretation gives a different set of admissible paths and hence a different answer.

Because the wording leaves those key points undecided, every solution I can construct depends on extra assumptions that are not forced by the statement itself; different reasonable assumptions lead to different wedding dates and different “longest routes”.

I therefore have no logically certain answer to give.

Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
Response:
Final answer:  
The eldest son (whose bride lives in the first village clockwise from their own) has only one “ever‑closer’’ route, so he brings his father‑in‑law a fish on 1 April and is married the next day, 2 April.  
The second son (bride in the second village clockwise) has three such routes, so his last trip is 3 April and his wedding is 4 April.  
The youngest son (bride in the third village clockwise, i.e. the village diametrically opposite their own) has nine routes, so his last trip is 9 April and he marries on 10 April.

Bonus:  
With the island’s circumference 10 mi the radius is 5⁄π mi; the side of the inscribed regular hexagon is also 5⁄π mi.  
The longest of the nine routes used by the youngest son is  
side + diameter + side = (5⁄π) + (10⁄π) + (5⁄π) = 20⁄π ≈ 6.37 mi.

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.

The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.

To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.

The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3

Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25

A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D

Response:
Because the six coastal villages lie at the six vertices of a regular hexagon, every straight path from one village to any other is a chord of that hexagon.  
Three different chord–lengths occur

• between adjacent villages: length R (the radius of the island),  
• between “second‑neighbours”: √3·R,  
• between opposite villages (diameters): 2 R,

where R = perimeter ⁄ 2π = (10 mi) ⁄ 2π = 5∕π miles.

Let us number the villages 0,1,2,3,4,5 clockwise.  
The father and all three of his sons live in village 0.  
The young ladies live in the first three villages one meets when going clockwise from 0, i.e. in villages 1, 2 and 3.  
Thus the three courtships are

son A : 0 → 1 (adjacent)  
son B : 0 → 2 (two steps round the coast)  
son C : 0 → 3 (the diametrically opposite village)

The rule “always get closer to the goal’’ means that, for a fixed goal, we may move only to villages whose distance from the goal is strictly smaller than the distance we had before.  
For any goal the possible distances are, successively, 2R → √3 R → R → 0, so at most three moves are ever needed.

Counting the allowable routes.

1.  From 0 to 1 (distance R → 0).  
The only way is the direct chord 0–1.  
Number of routes = 1.

2.  From 0 to 2 (distance √3 R → R → 0).  
Either go straight (0–2) or visit one of the two R–distant villages (1 or 3) first.  
So:
 0–2  
 0–1–2  
 0–3–2  
Number of routes = 3.

3.  From 0 to 3 (distance 2R → √3 R → R → 0).  
Possibilities:

 a) 0–3  
 b) 0–(1 or 5)–3   (two choices)  
 c) 0–(2 or 4)–3   (two choices)  
 d) 0–(1 or 5)–(2 or 4)–3 (four choices)

Total 1+2+2+4 = 9 different routes.

Hence the number of days each suitor must bring a fish is

son A : 1 day  
son B : 3 days  
son C : 9 days

All three start on 1 April.

Last fishing day → wedding day
1 April     → 2 April  
3 April     → 4 April  
9 April     → 10 April  

So the weddings occur on 2 April, 4 April and 10 April.

Bonus – the longest single route any son walks.  
The longest admissible route is one of the 9 routes from village 0 to village 3 that uses the longest possible chords, for example

0 → 1 (length R) → 4 (length 2 R) → 3 (length R).

Its total length is R + 2 R + R = 4 R = 4·(5∕π) = 20∕π miles  
≈ 6.366 miles.

Final answer:  
The three wedding days are April 2 nd, April 4 th and April 10 th.  
(The longest permissible route is 20⁄π ≈ 6.37 miles long.)

Response:
Symbolic Prompt: 

Constants
  n = 6                     // number of villages
  V = {v0 , v1 , v2 , v3 , v4 , v5}     // clockwise order around the coast
  Sons = {S1 , S2 , S3}                 // the three suitors
  Brides = {B1 , B2 , B3}               // their intended brides
  Start‑Date = 1 April                  // courtship begins this day
  R = circumference / (2π)              // island radius, if needed for lengths

Derived constants
  BrideVillage(Bi) = vi        for i = 1,2,3      // first three villages clockwise
  HomeVillage(Si)  = v0                         // all three sons start from v0

Primitive relations and functions
  Edge(u , v)                    // true iff the straight chord from u to v exists  
                                 // (Edge is the complete graph on V \times V \ {=} )
  Dist(u , v) ∈ ℝ^{+}            // Euclidean length of Edge(u , v)
  Path(P)                        // P is a finite list 〈p0 , … , pk〉 of distinct villages
  First(P) , Last(P)             // first and last village of path P
  Length(P) = Σ_{j=0}^{k‑1} Dist(pj , p_{j+1})

Definitions
  MonotoneToward(P , t)  ≡  ∀j (0 ≤ j < |P|‑1 → Dist(p_{j+1} , t) < Dist(p_j , t))
                              // every step strictly decreases the distance to target t

  ValidRoute(s , P)  ≡  Path(P)
                       ∧ First(P)=HomeVillage(s)
                       ∧ Last(P)=BrideVillage(s)
                       ∧ MonotoneToward(P , BrideVillage(s))

  RouteSet(s) = { P | ValidRoute(s , P) }         // all permissible routes for son s
  TripsRequired(s) = |RouteSet(s)|                // one fish‑delivery trip per route
  WeddingDay(s) = Start‑Date + TripsRequired(s)   // marriage occurs the next day

Problem statements
  1.  Compute WeddingDay(S1) , WeddingDay(S2) , WeddingDay(S3).

Bonus statement
  LongestRoute = max_{s∈Sons} max_{P∈RouteSet(s)} Length(P)
  2.  Compute LongestRoute when circumference = 10 miles.
